title: Scammers caught on tape tricking pensioner out of £12,000
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Sep 5, 2015, 11:11 BST - UK Markets closed Scammers caught on tape tricking pensioner out of £12,000 By Robert Mendick | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 
Police are investigating three men who conned a 65-year-old woman in "number spoofing" fraud 
Growing numbers of pensioners are falling victim to a new sophisticated banking fraud. 
Scammers are using special computer software so that when they phone victims the number that shows up on the receiving telephone matches that of the bank's helpline printed on the back of debit cards. 
Criminal gangs are thought to have netted £24m last year from the new type of fraud - also known as 'vishing' or 'voice phishing'. 
In the latest case, now being investigated by police, a 65-year-old woman was tricked into transferring £12,000 to the fraudsters' account. 
• I lost £17,500 in 'vishing' scam - because 'I didn't watch The One Show' 
• Over-55s are four times more likely to be scammed 
Nargess Sadjady, 65, from west London, was telephoned by a man, who introduced himself as 'Mark' and claimed he was calling from her bank, Santander. 
The man claimed the bank was worried about fraudulent activity on her account. Mrs Sadjady was suspicious at first and the man reassured her by explaining she would receive another call from Santander's fraud department. 
A second man then telephoned her and crucially the number that appeared on Mrs (LSE: MRS.L - news ) Sadjady's phone matched the number printed on the back of her debit card. 
Mrs Sadjady subsequently told the BBC's Moneybox on Radio 4 she had been suspicious up until that point. 
"I wasn't sure, until they called my mobile from that phone number on the back of my card," she said. 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) went on to transfer £12,000 from her Santander account to another account with the Halifax that the conmen had set up in her name and then cleared out. 
The scam took one hour and 40 minutes worth of calls spread out over three hours. The calls were secretly recorded by Mrs Sadjady's son who has now handed the tapes to the police. 
And because Mrs Sadjady transferred the money voluntarily, the banks initially declined to reimburse her - as they are entitled to do. They relented after intervention from the BBC. 
"These scams are so sophisticated that people genuinely end up believing it is the bank, even though they know, potentially, that it doesn't sound quite right," said Tony Black, a senior fraud prevention officer with Financial Fraud Action UK.
